subsection.title: Convex Functions

para.sentence: A function f(x) is convex on (a,b) if f((1-t)c+td)\leq(1-t)f(c)+tf(d) for any c,d\in(a,b) , and t\in[0,1].

If f(x) is twice differentiable, then f(x) is convex iff f^{\prime\prime}(x)\geq 0 on (a,b).
A continuously differentiable function is convex iff the curve does not lie below its tangent at any point.

Suppose z(t)=x(t)+iy(t) , a\leq t\leq b , is an arc and a=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{n}=b.
Suppose the subarc z(t) , t\in[t_{j-1},t_{j}] is contained in a domain D_{j} , j=1,\dots,n.
The function f_{1}(z) on D_{1} is said to be analytically continued along the path z(t) , a\leq t\leq b , if there is a chain (f_{1},D_{1}) , (f_{2},D_{2}),\dots,(f_{n},D_{n}).

Analytic continuation is a powerful aid in establishing transformations or functional equations for complex variables, because it enables the problem to be reduced to: (a) deriving the transformation (or functional equation) with real variables; followed by (b) finding the domain on which the transformedfunction is analytic.
Let C be a simple closed contour consisting of a segment \mathit{AB} of the real axis and a contour in the upper half-plane joining the ends of \mathit{AB}.
Also, let f(z) be analytic within C , continuous within and on C , and real on \mathit{AB}.
Then f(z) can be continued analytically across \mathit{AB} by reflection, that is, f(\overline{z})=\overline{f(z)}.
Suppose f(z) is analytic in the annulus r_{1}<|z-z_{0}|<r_{2} , 0\leq r_{1}<r_{2}\leq\infty , and r\in(r_{1},r_{2}).

Then f(z)=\sum^{\infty}_{n=-\infty}a_{n}(z-z_{0})^{n}, where a_{n}=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z-z_{0}|=r}\frac{f(z)}{(z-z_{0})^{n+1}}\mathrm{d}z, and the integration contour is described once in the positive sense.
The series (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.ls.1) converges uniformly and absolutely on compact sets in the annulus.
Let r_{1}=0 , so that the annulus becomes the punctured neighborhood N : 0<|z-z_{0}|<r_{2} , and assume that f(z) is analytic in N , but not at z_{0}.
Then z=z_{0} is an isolated singularity of f(z).
This singularity is removable if a_{n}=0 for all n<0 , and in this case the Laurent series becomes the Taylor series.
Next, z_{0} is a pole if a_{n}\not=0 for at least one, but only finitely many, negative n.
If -n is the first negative integer (counting from -\infty ) with a_{-n}\not=0 , then z_{0} is a pole of order (or multiplicity) n.
Lastly, if a_{n}\not=0 for infinitely many negative n , then z_{0} is an isolated essential singularity.
The singularities of f(z) at infinity are classified in the same way as the singularities of f(1/z) at z=0.
An isolated singularity z_{0} is always removable when \lim_{z\to z_{0}}f(z) exists, for example (\sin z)/z at z=0.

The coefficient a_{-1} of (z-z_{0})^{-1} in the Laurent series for f(z) is called the residue of f(z) at z_{0} , and denoted by \Residue_{z=z_{0}}[f(z)] , \Residue\limits_{z=z_{0}}[f(z)] , or (when there is no ambiguity) \Residue[f(z)].
A function whose only singularities, other than the point at infinity, are poles is called a meromorphic function.
If the poles are infinite in number, then the point at infinity is called anessential singularity: it is the limit point of the poles.
In any neighborhood of an isolated essential singularity, however small, an analytic function assumes every value in \mathbb{C} with at most one exception.

If f(z) is analytic within a simple closed contour C , and continuous within and on C —except in both instances for a finite number of singularities within C —then \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C}f(z)\mathrm{d}z=\mbox{sum of the residues of $f(z)$ within $C$}.
Here and elsewhere in this subsection the path C is described in the positive sense.

If the singularities within C are poles and f(z) is analytic and nonvanishing on C , then N-P=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C}\frac{f^{\prime}(z)}{f(z)}\mathrm{d}z=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\Delta_{C}(\operatorname{ph}f(z)), where N and P are respectively the numbers of zeros and poles, counting multiplicity, of f within C , and \Delta_{C}(\operatorname{ph}f(z)) is the change in any continuous branch of \operatorname{ph}\left(f(z)\right) as z passes once around C in the positive sense.
For examples of applications see ( , pp. 252–254) .

In addition, \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C}\frac{zf^{\prime}(z)}{f(z)}\mathrm{d}z=\mbox{(sum of locations of zeros)}-\mbox{(sum of locations of poles)}, each location again being counted with multiplicity equal to that of the corresponding zero or pole.
If f(z) and g(z) are analytic on and inside a simple closed contour C , and |g(z)|<|f(z)| on C , then f(z) and f(z)+g(z) have the same number of zeros inside C.
If f(z) is analytic in a domain D , z_{0}\in D and |f(z)|\leq|f(z_{0})| for all z\in D , then f(z) is a constant in D.
Let D be a bounded domain with boundary \partial D and let \overline{D}=D\cup\partial D.
If f(z) is continuous on \overline{D} and analytic in D , then |f(z)| attains its maximum on \partial D.
If u(z) is harmonic in D , z_{0}\in D , and u(z)\leq u(z_{0}) for all z\in D , then u(z) is constant in D.
Moreover, if D is bounded and u(z) is continuous on \overline{D} and harmonic in D , then u(z) is maximum at some point on \partial D.
In |z|<R , if f(z) is analytic, |f(z)|\leq M , and f(0)=0 , then |f(z)|\leq\frac{M|z|}{R}\;\mbox{ and }\;|f^{\prime}(0)|\leq\frac{M}{R}.
Equalities hold iff f(z)=Az , where A is a constant such that \left|A\right|=M/R.
Functions which have more than one value at a given point z are calledmultivalued (or many-valued) functions.
Let F(z) be a multivalued function and D be a domain.
If we can assign a unique value f(z) to F(z) at each point of D , and f(z) is analytic on D , then f(z) is a branch of F(z).
F(z)=\sqrt{z} is two-valued for z\not=0.
If D=\mathbb{C}\setminus(-\infty,0] and z=re^{i\theta} , then one branch is \sqrt{r}e^{i\theta/2} , the other branch is -\sqrt{r}e^{i\theta/2} , with -\pi<\theta<\pi in both cases.
Similarly if D=\mathbb{C}\setminus[0,\infty) , then one branch is \sqrt{r}e^{i\theta/2} , the other branch is -\sqrt{r}e^{i\theta/2} , with 0<\theta<2\pi in both cases.
A cut domain is one from which the points on finitely many nonintersecting simple contours (§LABEL:sec:AL.CC.i) have been removed. Each contour is called a cut.
A cut neighborhood is formed by deleting a ray emanating from the center.
(Or more generally, a simple contour that starts at the center and terminates on the boundary.)
Suppose F(z) is multivalued and a is a point such that there exists a branch of F(z) in a cut neighborhood of a , but there does not exist a branch of F(z) in any punctured neighborhood of a.
Then a is abranch point of F(z).
For example, z=0 is a branch point of \sqrt{z}.
Branches can be constructed in two ways:
(a) By introducing appropriate cuts from the branch points and restricting F(z) to be single-valued in the cut plane (or domain).

(b) By specifying the value of F(z) at a point z_{0} (not a branch point), and requiring F(z) to be continuous on any path that begins at z_{0} and does not pass through any branch points or other singularities of F(z).

If the path circles a branch point at z=a , k times in the positive sense, and returns to z_{0} without encircling any other branch point, then its value is denoted conventionally as F((z_{0}-a)e^{2k\pi i}+a).
Let \alpha and \beta be real or complex numbers that are not integers.
The function F(z)=(1-z)^{\alpha}(1+z)^{\beta} is many-valued with branch points at \pm 1.
Branches of F(z) can be defined, for example, in the cut plane D obtained from \mathbb{C} by removing the real axis from 1 to \infty and from -1 to -\infty ; see Figure LABEL:fig:AL.FC.mm1.
One such branch is obtained by assigning (1-z)^{\alpha} and (1+z)^{\beta} their principal values (§LABEL:sec:EF.EXP.POW).
Alternatively, take z_{0} to be any point in D and set F(z_{0})=e^{\alpha\ln\left(1-z_{0}\right)}e^{\beta\ln\left(1+z_{0}\right)} where the logarithms assume their principal values.
(Thus if z_{0} is in the interval (-1,1) , then the logarithms are real.)Then the value of F(z) at any other point is obtained by analytic continuation.

Thus if F(z) is continued along a path that circles z=1 m times in the positive sense and returns to z_{0} without circling z=-1 , then F((z_{0}-1)e^{2m\pi i}+1)=e^{\alpha\ln\left(1-z_{0}\right)}e^{\beta\ln\left(1+ z_{0}\right)}e^{2\pi im\alpha}.

If the path also circles z=-1 n times in the clockwise or negative sense before returning to z_{0} , then the value of F(z_{0}) becomes e^{\alpha\ln\left(1-z_{0}\right)}e^{\beta\ln\left(1+z_{0}\right)}e^{2\pi im \alpha}e^{-2\pi in\beta}.
Suppose f(z) is analytic at z=z_{0} , f^{\prime}(z_{0})\not=0 , and f(z_{0})=w_{0}.

Then the equation f(z)=w has a unique solution z=F(w) analytic at w=w_{0} , and F(w)=z_{0}+\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}F_{n}(w-w_{0})^{n} in a neighborhood of w_{0} , where nF_{n} is the residue of 1/(f(z)-f(z_{0}))^{n} at z=z_{0}.
(In other words nF_{n} is the coefficient of (z-z_{0})^{-1} in the Laurent expansion of 1/(f(z)-f(z_{0}))^{n} in powers of (z-z_{0}) ; compare §LABEL:sec:AL.FC.ls.)
Furthermore, if g(z) is analytic at z_{0} , then g(F(w))=g(z_{0})+\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}G_{n}(w-w_{0})^{n}, where nG_{n} is the residue of g^{\prime}(z)/(f(z)-f(z_{0}))^{n} at z=z_{0}.
Suppose that f(z)=f(z_{0})+\sum^{\infty}_{n=0}f_{n}(z-z_{0})^{\mu+n}, where \mu>0 , f_{0}\not=0 , and the series converges in a neighborhood of z_{0}.
(For example, when \mu is an integer f(z)-f(z_{0}) has a zero of order \mu at z_{0}.

Then (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.if.1) has a solution z=F(w) , where F(w)=z_{0}+\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}F_{n}(w-w_{0})^{n/\mu} in a neighborhood of w_{0} , nF_{n} being the residue of 1/(f(z)-f(z_{0}))^{n/\mu} at z=z_{0}.
It should be noted that different branches of (w-w_{0})^{1/\mu} used in forming (w-w_{0})^{n/\mu} in (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.if.5) give rise to different solutions of (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.if.1).
Also, if in addition g(z) is analytic at z_{0} , then g(F(w))=g(z_{0})+\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}G_{n}(w-w_{0})^{n/\mu}, where nG_{n} is the residue of g^{\prime}(z)/(f(z)-f(z_{0}))^{n/\mu} at z=z_{0}.
Let D be a domain and [a,b] be a closed finite segment of the real axis.
Assume that for each t\in[a,b] , f(z,t) is an analytic function of z in D , and also that f(z,t) is a continuous function of both variables.
Then F(z)=\int^{b}_{a}f(z,t)\mathrm{d}t is analytic in D and its derivatives of all orders can be found by differentiating under the sign of integration.
This result is also true when b=\infty , or when f(z,t) has a singularity at t=b , with the following conditions.

For each t\in[a,b) , f(z,t) is analytic in D ; f(z,t) is a continuous function of both variables when z\in D and t\in[a,b) ; the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.fd.1) converges at b , and this convergence is uniform with respect to z in every compact subset S of D.

The last condition means that given \epsilon ( >0 ) there exists a number a_{0}\in[a,b) that is independent of z and is such that \left|\int_{a_{1}}^{b}f(z,t)\mathrm{d}t\right|<\epsilon, for all a_{1}\in[a_{0},b) and all z\in S ; compare §LABEL:sec:AL.FOT.ltf.
If |f(z,t)|\leq M(t) for z\in S and \int^{b}_{a}M(t)\mathrm{d}t converges, then the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.fd.1) converges uniformly and absolutely in S.
Let p_{k,m}=\prod_{n=k}^{m}(1+a_{n}).
If for some k\geq 1 , p_{k,m}\to p_{k}\not=0 as m\to\infty , then we say that the infinite product \prod^{\infty}_{n=1}(1+a_{n}) converges.
(The integer k may be greater than one to allow for a finite number of zero factors.)The convergence of the product is absolute if \prod^{\infty}_{n=1}(1+|a_{n}|) converges.

The product \prod^{\infty}_{n=1}(1+a_{n}) , with a_{n}\not=-1 for all n , converges iff \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}\ln\left(1+a_{n}\right) converges; and it converges absolutely iff \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}|a_{n}| converges.
Suppose a_{n}=a_{n}(z) , z\in D , a domain.
The convergence of the infinite product is uniform if the sequence of partial products converges uniformly.
Suppose that a_{n}(z) are analytic functions in D.

If there is an N , independent of z\in D , such that |\ln\left(1+a_{n}(z)\right)|\leq M_{n}, subject to n\geq N, and \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}M_{n}<\infty, then the product \prod^{\infty}_{n=1}(1+a_{n}(z)) converges uniformly to an analytic function p(z) in D , and p(z)=0 only when at least one of the factors 1+a_{n}(z) is zero in D.
This conclusion remains true if, in place of (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.ip.1),
|a_{n}(z)|\leq M_{n} for all n , and again \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}M_{n}<\infty.
If \{z_{n}\} is a sequence such that \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}|z_{n}^{-2}| is convergent, then P(z)=\prod^{\infty}_{n=1}\left(1-\frac{z}{z_{n}}\right)e^{z/z_{n}} is an entire function with zeros at z_{n}.
Suppose D is a domain, and F(z)=\prod^{\infty}_{n=1}a_{n}(z), subject to z\in D, where a_{n}(z) is analytic for all n\geq 1 , and the convergence of the product is uniform in any compact subset of D.
Then F(z) is analytic in D.
If, also, a_{n}(z)\neq 0 when n\geq 1 and z\in D , then F(z)\neq 0 on D and \frac{F^{\prime}(z)}{F(z)}=\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}\frac{a_{n}^{\prime}(z)}{a_{n}(z )}.

If \{a_{n}\} and \{z_{n}\} are sequences such that z_{m}\neq z_{n} ( m\neq n ) and \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}|a_{n}z_{n}^{-2}| is convergent, then f(z)=\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}a_{n}\left(\frac{1}{z-z_{n}}+\frac{1}{z_{n}}\right) is analytic in \mathbb{C} , except for simple poles at z=z_{n} of residue a_{n}.
Then f(z)=(z-\alpha)(b_{n}z^{n-1}+b_{n-1}z^{n-2}+\dots+b_{1})+b_{0}, where b_{n}=a_{n} , b_{k}=\alpha b_{k+1}+a_{k}, subject to k=n-1,n-2,\dots,0, f(\alpha)=b_{0}.
With b_{k} as in (LABEL:eq:AL.ZP.da.1)–(LABEL:eq:AL.ZP.da.2a) let c_{n}=a_{n} and c_{k}=\alpha c_{k+1}+b_{k}, subject to k=n-1,n-2,\dots,1.
Then f^{\prime}(\alpha)=c_{1}.
More generally, for polynomials f(z) and g(z) , there are polynomials q(z) and r(z) , found by equating coefficients, such that f(z)=g(z)q(z)+r(z), where 0\leq\deg r(z)<\deg g(z).
A polynomial of degree n with real or complex coefficients has exactly n real or complex zeros counting multiplicity.
Every monic (coefficient of highest power is one) polynomial of odd degree with real coefficients has at least one real zero with sign opposite to that of the constant term.
A monic polynomial of even degree with real coefficients has at least two zeros of opposite signs when the constant term is negative.
The number of positive zeros of a polynomial with real coefficients cannot exceed the number of times the coefficients change sign, and the two numbers have same parity.
A similar relation holds for the changes in sign of the coefficients of f(-z) , and hence for the number of negative zeros of f(z).
Both polynomials have one change of sign; hence for each polynomial there is one positive zero, one negative zero, and six complex zeros.
Next, let f(z)=a_{n}z^{n}+a_{n-1}z^{n-1}+\dots+a_{0}.
The zeros of z^{n}f(1/z)=a_{0}z^{n}+a_{1}z^{n-1}+\dots+a_{n} are reciprocals of the zeros of f(z).
The discriminant of f(z) is defined by D=a_{n}^{2n-2}\prod_{j<k}(z_{j}-z_{k})^{2}, where z_{1},z_{2},\dots,z_{n} are the zeros of f(z).
The elementary symmetric functions of the zeros are (with a_{n}\not=0 )

\displaystyle z_{1}+z_{2}+\dots+z_{n}=-a_{n-1}/a_{n}, \displaystyle\sum_{1\leq j<k\leq n}z_{j}z_{k}=a_{n-2}/a_{n}, \displaystyle\mathrel{\vdots}, \displaystyle z_{1}z_{2}\cdots z_{n}=(-1)^{n}a_{0}/a_{n}.

subsection.title: Polynomials of Degrees Two, Three, and Four

para.sentence: The roots of az^{2}+bz+c=0 are \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{D}}{2a}, D=b^{2}-4ac.
The sum and product of the roots are respectively -b/a and c/a.
Set z=w-\tfrac{1}{3}a to reduce f(z)=z^{3}+az^{2}+bz+c to g(w)=w^{3}+pw+q , with p=(3b-a^{2})/3 , q=(2a^{3}-9ab+27c)/27.
The discriminant of g(w) is D=-4p^{3}-27q^{2}.
Let A=\sqrt[3]{-\tfrac{27}{2}q+\tfrac{3}{2}\sqrt{-3D}}, B=-3p/A.
The roots of g(w)=0 are \tfrac{1}{3}(A+B), \tfrac{1}{3}(\rho A+\rho^{2}B), \tfrac{1}{3}(\rho^{2}A+\rho B), with \rho=-\tfrac{1}{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-3}=e^{2\pi i/3}, \rho^{2}=e^{-2\pi i/3}.
Addition of -\frac{1}{3}a to each of these roots gives the roots of f(z)=0.
Roots of f(z)=0 are 2+\sqrt[3]{4}+\sqrt[3]{2} , 2+\sqrt[3]{4}\rho+\sqrt[3]{2}\rho^{2} , 2+\sqrt[3]{4}\rho^{2}+\sqrt[3]{2}\rho.
For another method see §LABEL:sec:EF.CE.

For the roots \alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3},\alpha_{4} of g(w)=0 and the roots \theta_{1},\theta_{2},\theta_{3} of the resolvent cubic equation z^{3}-2pz^{2}+(p^{2}-4r)z+q^{2}=0, we have 2\alpha_{1}=\phantom{+}\sqrt{-\theta_{1}}+\sqrt{-\theta_{2}}+\sqrt{-\theta_{3}}, 2\alpha_{2}=\phantom{+}\sqrt{-\theta_{1}}-\sqrt{-\theta_{2}}-\sqrt{-\theta_{3}}, 2\alpha_{3}=-\sqrt{-\theta_{1}}+\sqrt{-\theta_{2}}-\sqrt{-\theta_{3}}, 2\alpha_{4}=-\sqrt{-\theta_{1}}-\sqrt{-\theta_{2}}+\sqrt{-\theta_{3}}.
The square roots are chosen so that \sqrt{-\theta_{1}}\;\sqrt{-\theta_{2}}\;\sqrt{-\theta_{3}}=-q.
Add -\tfrac{1}{4}a to the roots of g(w)=0 to get those of f(z)=0.

Resolvent cubic is z^{3}+12z^{2}+20z+9=0 with roots \theta_{1}=-1 , \theta_{2}=-\tfrac{1}{2}(11+\sqrt{85}) , \theta_{3}=-\tfrac{1}{2}(11-\sqrt{85}) , and \sqrt{-\theta_{1}}=1 , \sqrt{-\theta_{2}}=\tfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{17}+\sqrt{5}) , \sqrt{-\theta_{3}}=\tfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{17}-\sqrt{5}).
So 2\alpha_{1}=1+\sqrt{17} , 2\alpha_{2}=1-\sqrt{17} , 2\alpha_{3}=-1+\sqrt{5} , 2\alpha_{4}=-1-\sqrt{5} , and the roots of f(z)=0 are \tfrac{1}{2}(3\pm\sqrt{17}) , \tfrac{1}{2}(1\pm\sqrt{5}).

subsection.title: Roots of Unity and of Other Constants

para.sentence: The roots of z^{n}-1=(z-1)(z^{n-1}+z^{n-2}+\dots+z+1)=0 are 1 , e^{2\pi i/n} , e^{4\pi i/n},\dots,e^{(2n-2)\pi i/n} , and of z^{n}+1=0 they are e^{\pi i/n},e^{3\pi i/n},\dots,e^{(2n-1)\pi i/n}.

The roots of z^{n}=a+ib, subject to a,b real, are \sqrt[n]{R}\left(\cos\left(\frac{\alpha+2k\pi}{n}\right)+i\sin\left(\frac{ \alpha+2k\pi}{n}\right)\right), where R=(a^{2}+b^{2})^{1/2} , \alpha=\operatorname{ph}\left(a+ib\right) , with the principal value of phase (§LABEL:sec:AL.CC.cn), and k=0,1,\dots,n-1.
f(z)=a_{0}+a_{1}z+\dots+a_{n}z^{n}, with real coefficients, is called stable if the real parts of all thezeros are strictly negative.

Let D_{1}=a_{1}, D_{2}=\begin{vmatrix}a_{1}&a_{3}\\ a_{0}&a_{2}\end{vmatrix}, D_{3}=\begin{vmatrix}a_{1}&a_{3}&a_{5}\\ a_{0}&a_{2}&a_{4}\\ 0&a_{1}&a_{3}\end{vmatrix}, and D_{k}=\det[h_{k}^{(1)},h_{k}^{(3)},\dots,h_{k}^{(2k-1)}], where the column vector h_{k}^{(m)} consists of the first k members of the sequence a_{m},a_{m-1},a_{m-2},\dots with a_{j}=0 if j<0 or j>n.

Then f(z) , with a_{n}\not=0 , is stable iff a_{0}\not=0 ; D_{2k}>0 , k=1,\dots,\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}n\right\rfloor ; \operatorname{sign}D_{2k+1}=\operatorname{sign}a_{0} , k=0,1,\dots,\left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}n-\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor.

The notation used throughout the DLMF for the continued fraction \cfracstyle{d}b_{0}+\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\raisebox{-6.0pt}{ $\ddots$}}} is b_{0}+\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+}}\cdots.
C=b_{0}+\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\cdots}}, subject to a_{n}\not=0, C_{n}=b_{0}+\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\cdots\cfrac{a_{n}}{b_{n}} }}=\frac{A_{n}}{B_{n}}.
C_{n} is called the n th approximant or convergent to C.
A_{n} and B_{n} are called the n th(canonical) numerator and denominator respectively.
Two continued fractions are equivalent if they have the sameconvergents.

b_{0}+\displaystyle{\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\cdots}}} is equivalent to b^{\prime}_{0}+\displaystyle{\cfrac{a^{\prime}_{1}}{b^{\prime}_{1}+\cfrac{a^{ \prime}_{2}}{b^{\prime}_{2}+\cdots}}} if there is a sequence \{d_{n}\}^{\infty}_{n=0} , d_{0}=1 , d_{n}\neq 0 , such that a^{\prime}_{n}=d_{n}d_{n-1}a_{n}, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots, and b^{\prime}_{n}=d_{n}b_{n}, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots.

p_{0}+\sum^{n}_{k=1}p_{1}p_{2}\cdots p_{k}=p_{0}+\cfrac{p_{1}}{1-\cfrac{p_{2}} {1+p_{2}-\cfrac{p_{3}}{1+p_{3}-\cdots\cfrac{p_{n}}{1+p_{n}}}}}, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, when p_{k}\not=0 , k=1,2,3,\dots.

\sum^{n}_{k=0}c_{k}x^{k}=c_{0}+\cfrac{c_{1}x}{1-\cfrac{(\ifrac{c_{2}}{c_{1}})x }{1+(\ifrac{c_{2}}{c_{1}})x-\cfrac{(\ifrac{c_{3}}{c_{2}})x}{1+(\ifrac{c_{3}}{c _{2}})x-\cdots\cfrac{(\ifrac{c_{n}}{c_{n-1}})x}{1+(\ifrac{c_{n}}{c_{n-1}})x}}}}, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, when c_{k}\not=0 , k=1,2,3,\dots.
Define C_{n}(w)=b_{0}+\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\cdots\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n }+w}}}.

A sequence \{C_{n}\} in the extended complex plane, \mathbb{C}\cup\{\infty\} , can be a sequence of convergents of the continued fraction (LABEL:eq:AL.CF.Co.1) iff C_{0}\not=\infty, C_{n}\not=C_{n-1}, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.
A contraction of a continued fraction C is a continued fraction C^{\prime} whose convergents \{C^{\prime}_{n}\} form a subsequence of the convergents \{C_{n}\} of C.
Conversely, C is called an extension of C^{\prime}.
If C^{\prime}_{n}=C_{2n} , n=0,1,2,\dots , then C^{\prime} is called the even part of C.
If C^{\prime}_{n}=C_{2n+1} , n=0,1,2,\dots , then C^{\prime} is called the odd part of C.
A continued fraction converges if the convergents C_{n} tend to a finite limit as n\to\infty.
The continued fraction \displaystyle{\cfrac{a_{1}}{b_{1}+\cfrac{a_{2}}{b_{2}+\cdots}}} converges when |b_{n}|\geq|a_{n}|+1, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots.
With these conditions the convergents C_{n} satisfy |C_{n}|<1 and C_{n}\to C with |C|\leq 1.

Let the elements of the continued fraction \displaystyle{\cfrac{1}{b_{1}+\cfrac{1}{b_{2}+\cdots}}} satisfy -\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+\delta<\operatorname{ph}b_{n}<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\delta, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots, where \delta is an arbitrary small positive constant.

Then the convergents C_{n} satisfy -\tfrac{1}{2}\pi+\delta<\operatorname{ph}C_{n}<\tfrac{1}{2}\pi-\delta, subject to n=1,2,3,\dots, and the even and odd parts of the continued fraction converge to finite values.
The continued fraction converges iff, in addition, \sum^{\infty}_{n=1}|b_{n}|=\infty.
In this case |\operatorname{ph}C|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi.
For analytical and numerical applications of continued fractions to special functions see §LABEL:sec:NM.CFR.
A domain in the complex plane is simply-connected if it has no “holes”; more precisely, if its complement in the extended plane \mathbb{C}\cup\{\infty\} is connected.

The equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+f(z)\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z }+g(z)w=0, where z\in D , a simply-connected domain, and f(z) , g(z) are analytic in D , has an infinite number of analytic solutions in D.
A solution becomes unique, for example, when w and \ifrac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} are prescribed at a point in D.
Two solutions w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) are called a fundamental pair if any other solution w(z) is expressible as w(z)=Aw_{1}(z)+Bw_{2}(z), where A and B are constants.
A fundamental pair can be obtained, for example, by taking any z_{0}\in D and requiring that w_{1}(z_{0})=1, w_{1}^{\prime}(z_{0})=0, w_{2}(z_{0})=0, w_{2}^{\prime}(z_{0})=1.
The Wronskian of w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) is defined by \mathscr{W}\left\{w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z)\right\}=w_{1}(z)w_{2}^{\prime}(z)-w_{2}(z) w_{1}^{\prime}(z).
Then \mathscr{W}\left\{w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z)\right\}=ce^{-\int f(z)\mathrm{d}z}, where c is independent of z.
If f(z)=0 , then the Wronskian is constant.

The following three statements are equivalent: w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) comprise a fundamental pair in D ; \mathscr{W}\left\{w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z)\right\} does not vanish in D ; w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) are linearly independent, that is, the only constants A and B such that Aw_{1}(z)+Bw_{2}(z)=0, subject to \forall z\in D, are A=B=0.

Assume that in the equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+f(u,z)\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d }z}+g(u,z)w=0, u and z belong to domains U and D respectively, the coefficients f(u,z) and g(u,z) are continuous functions of both variables, and for each fixed u (fixed z ) the two functions are analytic in z (in u ). Suppose also that at (a fixed) z_{0}\in D , w and \ifrac{\partial w}{\partial z} are analytic functions of u.
Then at each z\in D , w , \ifrac{\partial w}{\partial z} and \ifrac{{\partial}^{2}w}{{\partial z}^{2}} are analytic functions of u.

The inhomogeneous (or nonhomogeneous) equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+f(z)\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z }+g(z)w=r(z) with f(z) , g(z) , and r(z) analytic in D has infinitely many analytic solutions in D.

If w_{0}(z) is any one solution, and w_{1}(z) , w_{2}(z) are a fundamental pair of solutions of the corresponding homogeneous equation (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1), then every solution of (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.nh.1) can be expressed as w(z)=w_{0}(z)+Aw_{1}(z)+Bw_{2}(z), where A and B are constants.

With the notation of (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.nh.1) and (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.nh.2) w_{0}(z)=w_{2}(z)\int\frac{w_{1}(z)r(z)}{\mathscr{W}\left\{w_{1}(z),w_{2}(z) \right\}}\mathrm{d}z-w_{1}(z)\int\frac{w_{2}(z)r(z)}{\mathscr{W}\left\{w_{1}(z ),w_{2}(z)\right\}}\mathrm{d}z.

paragraph.title: Transformation of the Point at Infinity

para.sentence: The substitution \xi=1/z in (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1) gives \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\xi}^{2}}+F(\xi)\frac{\mathrm{d}W}{\mathrm {d}\xi}+G(\xi)W=0, where W(\xi)=w\left(\frac{1}{\xi}\right), F(\xi)=\frac{2}{\xi}-\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}f\left(\frac{1}{\xi}\right), G(\xi)=\frac{1}{\xi^{4}}g\left(\frac{1}{\xi}\right).

paragraph.title: Elimination of First Derivative by Change of Dependent Variable

para.sentence: The substitution w(z)=W(z)\exp\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\int f(z)\mathrm{d}z\right) in (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1) gives \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}-H(z)W=0, where H(z)=\tfrac{1}{4}f^{2}(z)+\tfrac{1}{2}f^{\prime}(z)-g(z).

paragraph.title: Elimination of First Derivative by Change of Independent Variable

para.sentence: In (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1) substitute \eta=\int\exp\left(-\int f(z)\mathrm{d}z\right)\mathrm{d}z.
Then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}\eta}^{2}}+g(z)\exp\left(2\int f(z)\mathrm {d}z\right)w=0.
Let W(z) satisfy (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.cv.4),
\zeta(z) be any thrice-differentiable function of z , and U(z)=(\zeta^{\prime}(z))^{1/2}W(z).
Then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}U}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=\left(\dot{z}^{2}H(z)-\tfrac{1 }{2}\left\{z,\zeta\right\}\right)U.

Here dots denote differentiations with respect to \zeta , and \left\{z,\zeta\right\} is the Schwarzian derivative: \left\{z,\zeta\right\}=-2\dot{z}^{\ifrac{1}{2}}\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{ \mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}(\dot{z}^{-\ifrac{1}{2}})=\frac{\dddot{z}}{\dot{z}}-\frac {3}{2}\left(\frac{\ddot{z}}{\dot{z}}\right)^{2}.
For arbitrary \xi and \zeta , \left\{z,\zeta\right\}=(\ifrac{\mathrm{d}\xi}{\mathrm{d}\zeta})^{2}\left\{z, \xi\right\}+\left\{\xi,\zeta\right\}.
, \left\{z,\zeta\right\}=-(\ifrac{\mathrm{d}z}{\mathrm{d}\zeta})^{2}\left\{\zeta ,z\right\}.

The product of any two solutions of (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1) satisfies \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{3}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{3}}+3f\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{ \mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(2f^{2}+f^{\prime}+4g)\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+(4fg+2 g^{\prime})w=0.

If U(z) and V(z) are respectively solutions of \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}U}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+IU=0, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}V}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+JV=0, then W=UV is a solution of \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\frac{W^{\prime\prime\prime}+2(I+J)W^{ \prime}+(I^{\prime}+J^{\prime})W}{I-J}\right)=-(I-J)W.
For extensions of these results to linear homogeneous differential equations of arbitrary order see ( ) .
For classification of singularities of (LABEL:eq:AL.DE.es.1) and expansions of solutions in the neighborhoods of singularities, see §LABEL:sec:AS.DE.
For an extensive collection of solutions of differential equations of the first, second, and higher orders see ( ) .

The Fourier transform of a real- or complex-valued function f(t) is defined by \mathscr{F}\left(f\right)\left(x\right)=\mathscr{F}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)e^{ixt}\mathrm{ d}t.
(Some references replace ixt by -ixt ).
The same notation \mathscr{F} is used for Fourier transforms of functionsof several variables and for Fourier transforms of distributions; see §LABEL:sec:AL.DI.FT.
In this subsection we let F(x)=\mathscr{F}\left(f\right)\left(x\right).
If f(t) is absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then F(x) is continuous, F(x)\to 0 as x\to\pm\infty , and |F(x)|\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|f(t)|\mathrm{d}t.
Suppose that f(t) is absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty) and of bounded variation in a neighborhood of t=u (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.di).
Then \tfrac{1}{2}(f(u+)+f(u-))=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\pvint^{\infty}_{-\infty}F(x)e^ {-ixu}\mathrm{d}x, where the last integral denotes the Cauchy principal value (LABEL:eq:AL.COO.di.5a).
In many applications f(t) is absolutely integrable and f^{\prime}(t) is continuous on (-\infty,\infty).
Then f(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}F(x)e^{-ixt}\mathrm{d}x.
For Fourier transforms, the convolution (f*g)(t) of two functions f(t) and g(t) defined on (-\infty,\infty) is given by (f*g)(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t-s)g(s)\mathrm{d}s.
If f(t) and g(t) are absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then so is (f*g)(t) , and its Fourier transform is F(x)G(x) , where G(x) is the Fourier transform of g(t).

Suppose f(t) and g(t) are absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then (f*g)(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}F(x)G(x)e^{-itx}\mathrm{d }x, \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}F(x)G(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)g(-t) \mathrm{d}t, \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|F(x)|^{2}\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|f(t)|^{2} \mathrm{d}t.
(LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.8) is Parseval’s formula.
If f(t) and g(t) are continuous and absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , and F(x)=G(x) for all x , then f(t)=g(t) for all t.

The Fourier cosine transform and Fourier sine transform are defined respectively by \mathscr{F}_{\mskip-3.0mu c}\left(f\right)\left(x\right)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-3 .0mu c}\mskip-1.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int^{ \infty}_{0}f(t)\cos\left(xt\right)\mathrm{d}t, , \mathscr{F}_{\mskip-2.0mu s}\left(f\right)\left(x\right)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-2 .0mu s}\mskip-1.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int^{ \infty}_{0}f(t)\sin\left(xt\right)\mathrm{d}t.

In this subsection we let F_{c}(x)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-3.0mu c}\mskip-1.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right) , F_{s}(x)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-2.0mu s}\mskip-1.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right) , G_{c}(x)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-3.0mu c}\mskip-1.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right) , and G_{s}(x)=\mathscr{F}_{\mskip-2.0mu s}\mskip-1.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right).

If f(t) is absolutely integrable on [0,\infty) and of bounded variation (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.di) in a neighborhood of t=u , then \tfrac{1}{2}(f(u+)+f(u-))=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{0}F_{c}(x)\cos \left(ux\right)\mathrm{d}x, , \tfrac{1}{2}(f(u+)+f(u-))=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{0}F_{s}(x)\sin \left(ux\right)\mathrm{d}x.

If \int^{\infty}_{0}|f(t)|\mathrm{d}t<\infty , g(t) is of bounded variation on (0,\infty) and g(t)\to 0 as t\to\infty , then \int^{\infty}_{0}F_{c}(x)G_{c}(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{0}f(t)g(t)\mathrm{ d}t, , \int^{\infty}_{0}F_{s}(x)G_{s}(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{0}f(t)g(t)\mathrm{ d}t, \int^{\infty}_{0}(F_{c}(x))^{2}\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{0}(f(t))^{2}\mathrm{ d}t, , \int^{\infty}_{0}(F_{s}(x))^{2}\mathrm{d}x=\int^{\infty}_{0}(f(t))^{2}\mathrm{ d}t.
Suppose f(t) is a real- or complex-valued function and s is a real or complex parameter.
The Laplace transform of f is defined by \mathscr{L}\left(f\right)\left(s\right)=\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\int^{\infty}_{0}e^{-st}f(t)\mathrm{d}t.
Assume that f(t) is piecewise continuous on [0,\infty) and ofexponential growth, that is, constants M and \alpha exist such that |f(t)|\leq Me^{\alpha t}, subject to 0\leq t<\infty.
Then \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right) is an analytic function of s for \Re s>\alpha.
Moreover, \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\to 0, subject to \Re s\to\infty.
Throughout the remainder of this subsection we assume (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.lt.2) is satisfied and \Re s>\alpha.

If f(t) is continuous and f^{\prime}(t) is piecewise continuous on [0,\infty) , then f(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\lim_{T\to\infty}\int^{\sigma+iT}_{\sigma-iT}e^{ts} \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\mathrm{d}s, subject to \sigma>\alpha.
Moreover, if \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=O\left(s^{-K}\right) in some half-plane \Re s\geq\gamma and K>1 , then (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.lt.13) holds for \sigma>\gamma.
If \Re s>\max(\Re(a+\alpha),\alpha) , then \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s-a\right)=\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f_{a}\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right), where f_{a}(t)=e^{at}f(t).

Also, if a\geq 0 then \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f_{a}^{+}\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=e^{-as}\mathscr{L }\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right), where f^{+}_{a}(t)=H\left(t-a\right)f(t-a) and H is the Heaviside function; see (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.HF.1).

If f(t) is piecewise continuous, then {(-1)}^{n}\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}s}^{n}}\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f_{n}\mskip 3.0mu \left(s \right), subject to n=1,2,3,\dots, where f_{n}(t)=t^{n}f(t).

If also \lim_{t\to 0+}f(t)/t exists, then \int^{\infty}_{s}\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(u\right)\mathrm{d }u=\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f_{-1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right), where f_{-1}(t)=\frac{f(t)}{t}.
If a>0 and f(t+a)=f(t) for t>0 , then \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\frac{1}{1-e^{-as}}\int^{ a}_{0}e^{-st}f(t)\mathrm{d}t.
Alternatively if f(t+a)=-f(t) for t>0 , then \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-as}}\int^{ a}_{0}e^{-st}f(t)\mathrm{d}t.
If f(t) is continuous on [0,\infty) and f^{\prime}(t) is piecewise continuous on (0,\infty) , then \mathscr{L}\left(f^{\prime}\right)\left(s\right)=s\mathscr{L}\left(f\right) \left(s\right)-f(0+).

If f(t) and f^{\prime}(t) are piecewise continuous on [0,\infty) with discontinuities at ( 0= ) t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{n} , then \mathscr{L}\left(f^{\prime}\right)\left(s\right)=s\mathscr{L}\left(f\right) \left(s\right)-f(0+)-\sum^{n}_{k=1}e^{-st_{k}}(f(t_{k}+)-f(t_{k}-)).
Next, assume f(t) , f^{\prime}(t) , \dots , f^{(n-1)}(t) are continuous and each satisfies (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.lt.2).
Also assume that f^{(n)}(t) is piecewise continuous on [0,\infty).
Then \mathscr{L}\left(f^{(n)}\right)\left(s\right)=s^{n}\mathscr{L}\left(f\right) \left(s\right)-s^{n-1}f(0+)-s^{n-2}f^{\prime}(0+)-\dots-f^{(n-1)}(0+).
For Laplace transforms, the convolution of two functions f(t) and g(t) , defined on [0,\infty) , is (f*g)(t)=\int^{t}_{0}f(u)g(t-u)\mathrm{d}u.
If f(t) and g(t) are piecewise continuous, then \mathscr{L}\left(f*g\right)=\mathscr{L}\left(f\right)\mathscr{L}\left(g\right).
If f(t) and g(t) are continuous and \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu g \mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right) , then f(t)=g(t).

The Mellin transform of a real- or complex-valued function f(x) is defined by \mathscr{M}\left(f\right)\left(s\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\int^{\infty}_{0}x^{s-1}f(x)\mathrm{d}x.

If x^{\sigma-1}f(x) is integrable on (0,\infty) for all \sigma in a<\sigma<b , then the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.33) converges and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right) is an analytic function of s in the vertical strip a<\Re s<b.
Moreover, for a<\sigma<b , \lim_{t\to\pm\infty}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(\sigma+it \right)=0.

Note: If f(x) is continuous and \alpha and \beta are real numbers such that f(x)=O\left(x^{\alpha}\right) as x\to 0+ and f(x)=O\left(x^{\beta}\right) as x\to\infty , then x^{\sigma-1}f(x) is integrable on (0,\infty) for all \sigma\in(-\alpha,-\beta).
Suppose the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.33) is absolutely convergent on the line \Re s=\sigma and f(x) is of bounded variation in a neighborhood of x=u.
Then \tfrac{1}{2}(f(u+)+f(u-))=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\lim_{T\to\infty}\int^{\sigma+iT}_{ \sigma-iT}u^{-s}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\mathrm{d}s.

If f(x) is continuous on (0,\infty) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(\sigma+it\right) is integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then f(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int^{\sigma+i\infty}_{\sigma-i\infty}x^{-s}\mathscr{M} \mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\mathrm{d}s.

Suppose x^{-\sigma}f(x) and x^{\sigma-1}g(x) are absolutely integrable on (0,\infty) and either \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(\sigma+it\right) or \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-\sigma-it\right) is absolutely integrable on (-\infty,\infty).

Then for y>0 , \int^{\infty}_{0}f(x)g(yx)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\*\int^{\sigma+i\infty}_ {\sigma-i\infty}y^{-s}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-s\right) \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\mathrm{d}s, \int^{\infty}_{0}f(x)g(x)\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\*\int^{\sigma+i\infty}_{ \sigma-i\infty}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-s\right)\mathscr{ M}\mskip-3.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)\mathrm{d}s.

When f is real and \sigma=\tfrac{1}{2} , \int^{\infty}_{0}(f(x))^{2}\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}{ \left|\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(\tfrac{1}{2}+it\right)\right |^{2}}\mathrm{d}t.
Let (f*g)(x)=\int^{\infty}_{0}f(y)g\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{y}.

If x^{\sigma-1}f(x) and x^{\sigma-1}g(x) are absolutely integrable on (0,\infty) , then for s=\sigma+it , \int^{\infty}_{0}x^{s-1}(f*g)(x)\mathrm{d}x=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3. 0mu \left(s\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu g\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right).

The Hilbert transform of a real-valued function f(t) is defined in the following equivalent ways: \mathcal{H}\left(f\right)\left(x\right)=\mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\frac{1}{\pi}\pvint^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{f(t)}{t-x}\mathrm{d }t, , \mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\lim_{y\to 0+}\frac{1}{ \pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{t-x}{(t-x)^{2}+y^{2}}f(t)\mathrm{d}t, , \mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)=\lim_{\epsilon\to 0+} \frac{1}{\pi}\int^{\infty}_{\epsilon}\frac{f(x+t)-f(x-t)}{t}\mathrm{d}t.
Suppose f(t) is continuously differentiable on (-\infty,\infty) and vanishes outside a bounded interval.
Then f(x)=-\frac{1}{\pi}\pvint^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(u\right)}{u-x}\mathrm{d}u.

If |f(t)|^{p} , p>1 , is integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then so is |\mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)|^{p} and \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|\mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right)|^ {p}\mathrm{d}x\leq A_{p}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|f(t)|^{p}\mathrm{d}t, where A_{p}=\tan\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi/p\right) when 1<p\leq 2 , or \cot\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\pi/p\right) when p\geq 2.
These bounds are sharp, and equality holds when p=2.
When f(t) satisfies the same conditions as those for (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.47),

\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathcal{H}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3. 0mu \left(u\right)e^{iux}\mathrm{d}u=-\mathrm{i}(\operatorname{sign}x)\mathscr {F}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right), where \mathscr{F}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(x\right) is given by (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.1).

The Stieltjes transform of a real-valued function f(t) is defined by \mathcal{S}\left(f\right)\left(s\right)=\mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right)=\int^{\infty}_{0}\frac{f(t)}{s+t}\mathrm{d}t.
Sufficient conditions for the integral to converge are that s is a positive real number, and f(t)=O\left(t^{-\delta}\right) as t\to\infty , where \delta>0.
If the integral converges, then it converges uniformly in any compact domain in the complex s -plane not containing any point of the interval (-\infty,0].

In this case, \mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(s\right) represents an analytic function in the s -plane cut along the negative real axis, and \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{m}}{{\mathrm{d}s}^{m}}\mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0 mu \left(s\right)=(-1)^{m}m!\int^{\infty}_{0}\frac{f(t)\mathrm{d}t}{(s+t)^{m+1 }}, subject to m=0,1,2,\dots.

If f(t) is absolutely integrable on [0,R] for every finite R , and the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.st.1) converges, then \lim_{t\to 0+}\frac{\mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(-\sigma-it \right)-\mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(-\sigma+it\right)}{2\pi i} =\tfrac{1}{2}(f(\sigma+)+f(\sigma-)), for all values of the positive constant \sigma for which the right-hand side exists.
If f(t) is piecewise continuous on [0,\infty) and the integral (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.st.1) converges, then \mathcal{S}\left(f\right)=\mathscr{L}\left(\mathscr{L}\left(f\right)\right).

As r\to 1- P(r,\theta)\to 0, uniformly for \theta\in[\delta,2\pi-\delta].
(Here and elsewhere in this subsection \delta is a constant such that 0<\delta<\pi.

For n=0,1,2,\dots , K_{n}(\theta)=\frac{1}{n+1}\left(\frac{\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(n+1)\theta\right )}{\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\theta\right)}\right)^{2}, \frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{2\pi}_{0}K_{n}(\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta=1.
As n\to\infty K_{n}(\theta)\to 0, uniformly for \theta\in[\delta,2\pi-\delta].
A(r,\theta)=\sum^{\infty}_{n=-\infty}r^{|n|}F(n)e^{in\theta}, where F(n)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{2\pi}_{0}f(t)e^{-int}\mathrm{d}t.
A(r,\theta) is a harmonic function in polar coordinates ((LABEL:eq:AL.CC.d.4)), and A(r,\theta)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{2\pi}_{0}P(r,\theta-t)f(t)\mathrm{d}t.
Let \sigma_{n}(\theta)=\frac{s_{0}(\theta)+s_{1}(\theta)+\dots+s_{n}(\theta)}{n+1}, n=0,1,2,\dots , where s_{n}(\theta)=\sum^{n}_{k=-n}F(k)e^{ik\theta}.
Then \sigma_{n}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{2\pi}_{0}K_{n}(\theta-t)f(t)\mathrm{d}t.

If f(\theta) is periodic and integrable on [0,2\pi] , then as n\to\infty the Abel means A(r,\theta) and the (C,1) means \sigma_{n}(\theta) converge to \tfrac{1}{2}(f(\theta+)+f(\theta-)) at every point \theta where both limits exist.
If f(\theta) is also continuous, then the convergence is uniform for all \theta.

For real-valued f(\theta) , if \sum^{\infty}_{n=-\infty}F(n)e^{in\theta} is the Fourier series of f(\theta) , then the series F(0)+2\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}F(n)e^{in\theta} can be extended to the interior of the unit circle as an analytic function G(z)=G(x+iy)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y)=F(0)+2\sum^{\infty}_{n=1}F(n)z^{n}.

Here u(x,y)=A(r,\theta) is the Abel (or Poisson) sum of f(\theta) , and v(x,y) has the series representation -\sum^{\infty}_{n=-\infty}i(\operatorname{sign}n)F(n)r^{|n|}e^{in\theta}; compare §LABEL:sec:AL.Su.SFI.

\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\mathrm{d}t is Abel summable to L , or \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\mathrm{d}t=L\;\;\;\textit{(A)}, when \lim_{\epsilon\to 0+}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}e^{-\epsilon|t|}f(t)\mathrm{d}t=L.

\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\mathrm{d}t is (C,1) summable to L , or \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\mathrm{d}t=L\;\;\;\textit{(C,1)}, when \lim_{R\to\infty}\int^{R}_{-R}\left(1-\frac{|t|}{R}\right)f(t)\mathrm{d}t=L.
If \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\mathrm{d}t converges and equals L , then the integral is Abel and Cesàro summable to L.
P(x,y)=\frac{2y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}, subject to y>0, -\infty<x<\infty.
\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}P(x,y)\mathrm{d}x=1.
For each \delta>0 , \int_{|x|\geq\delta}P(x,y)\mathrm{d}x\to 0, subject to as y\to 0.
Let h(x,y)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}e^{-y|t|}e^{-ixt}F(t) \mathrm{d}t, where F(t) is the Fourier transform of f(x) (§LABEL:sec:AL.IT.ft).
Then h(x,y)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)P(x-t,y)\mathrm{d}t is the Poisson integral of f(t).
If f(x) is integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then \lim_{y\to 0+}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|h(x,y)-f(x)|\mathrm{d}x=0.
Suppose now f(x) is real-valued and integrable on (-\infty,\infty).
Let \Phi(z)=\Phi(x+iy)=\frac{i}{\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\frac{1}{(x-t)+iy} \mathrm{d}t, where y>0 and -\infty<x<\infty.
Then \Phi(z) is an analytic function in the upper half-plane and its real part is the Poisson integral h(x,y) ; compare (LABEL:eq:AL.CC.i.10).
The imaginary part \Im\Phi(x+iy)=\frac{1}{\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)\frac{x-t}{(x-t)^{2}+y^{ 2}}\mathrm{d}t is the conjugate Poisson integral of f(x).
Moreover, \lim_{y\to 0+}\Im\Phi(x+iy) is the Hilbert transform of f(x) (§LABEL:sec:AL.IT.ht).
K_{R}(s)=\frac{1}{\pi R}\frac{1-\cos\left(Rs\right)}{s^{2}}, \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}K_{R}(s)\mathrm{d}s=1.
For each \delta>0 , \int_{|s|\geq\delta}K_{R}(s)\mathrm{d}s\to 0, subject to as R\to\infty.
Let \sigma_{R}(\theta)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int^{R}_{-R}\left(1-\frac{|t|}{R} \right)e^{-i\theta t}F(t)\mathrm{d}t, , \sigma_{R}(\theta)=\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}f(t)K_{R}(\theta-t)\mathrm{d}t.
If f(\theta) is integrable on (-\infty,\infty) , then \lim_{R\to\infty}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}|\sigma_{R}(\theta)-f(\theta)|\mathrm{ d}\theta=0.
For \Re\alpha>0 and x\geq 0 , the Riemann-Liouville fractional integral of order \alpha is defined by I^{\alpha}f(x)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(\alpha\right)}\int^{x}_{0}(x-t)^{\alpha-1} f(t)\mathrm{d}t.
For \Gamma\left(\alpha\right) see §LABEL:sec:GA.Def, and compare (LABEL:eq:AL.COO.RepInt) in the case when \alpha is a positive integer.
I^{\alpha}I^{\beta}=I^{\alpha+\beta}, subject to \Re\alpha>0, \Re\beta>0.
For extensions of (LABEL:eq:AL.Su.FIn.2) see ( ) .
If f(x)=\sum^{\infty}_{k=0}a_{k}x^{k}, then I^{\alpha}f(x)=\sum^{\infty}_{k=0}\frac{k!}{\Gamma\left(k+\alpha+1\right)}a_{k }x^{k+\alpha}.
The lower limit 0 of the integral in (LABEL:eq:AL.Su.FIn.1)can be replaced by any constant a\leq x.
Also, we can replace the lower and upper limits of the integral by x and a , respectively.
In that case we must also replace (x-t) in the integrand by (t-x) and we can even set a=\infty.
See (LABEL:eq:OP.CP.IN.FI.1), (LABEL:eq:OP.CP.IN.FI.2b) and (LABEL:eq:OP.CP.IN.FI.3b) as examples.

For 0<\Re\alpha<n , n an integer, and x\geq 0 , the fractional derivative of order \alpha is defined by D^{\alpha}f(x)=\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{n}}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{n}}I^{n-\alpha}f(x), and satisfies the property D^{k}I^{\alpha}=D^{n}I^{\alpha+n-k}, subject to k=1,2,\dots,n.
When none of \alpha , \beta , and \alpha+\beta is an integer D^{\alpha}D^{\beta}=D^{\alpha+\beta}.
Note that D^{1/2}D\not=D^{3/2}.
See also ( ) .
If \sum^{\infty}_{n=0}a_{n}=s\;\;\;\textit{(A)}, a_{n}>-\frac{K}{n} subject to n>0, K>0, then \sum^{\infty}_{n=0}a_{n}=s.
If \lim_{x\to 1-}(1-x)\sum^{\infty}_{n=0}a_{n}x^{n}=s, and either |a_{n}|\leq K or a_{n}\geq 0 , then \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{a_{0}+a_{1}+\dots+a_{n}}{n+1}=s.
Let \phi be a function defined on an open interval I=(a,b) , which can be infinite.
The closure of the set of points where \phi\not=0 is called thesupport of \phi.
If the support of \phi is a compact set (§LABEL:sec:AL.CC.il), then \phi is called a function of compact support.
A test function is an infinitely differentiable function of compact support.

A sequence \{\phi_{n}\} of test functions converges to a test function \phi if the support of every \phi_{n} is contained in a fixed compact set K and as n\to\infty the sequence \{\phi_{n}^{(k)}\} converges uniformly on K to \phi^{(k)} for k=0,1,2,\dots.
The linear space of all test functions with the above definition of convergence is called a test function space.
We denote it by \mathcal{D}(I).

A mapping \Lambda on \mathcal{D}(I) is a linear functional if it takes complex values and \Lambda(\alpha_{1}\phi_{1}+\alpha_{2}\phi_{2})=\alpha_{1}\Lambda(\phi_{1})+ \alpha_{2}\Lambda(\phi_{2}), where \alpha_{1} and \alpha_{2} are real or complex constants.

\Lambda:\mathcal{D}(I)\rightarrow\mathbb{C} is called a distribution if it is a continuous linear functional on \mathcal{D}(I) , that is, it is a linear functional and for every \phi_{n}\to\phi in \mathcal{D}(I) , \lim_{n\to\infty}\Lambda(\phi_{n})=\Lambda(\phi).
From here on we write \left\langle\Lambda,\phi\right\rangle for \Lambda(\phi).
The space of all distributions will be denoted by \mathcal{D}^{*}(I).

A distribution \Lambda is called regular if there is a function f on I , which is absolutely integrable on every compact subset of I , such that \left\langle\Lambda,\phi\right\rangle=\int_{I}f(x)\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x.
We denote a regular distribution by \Lambda_{f} , or simply f , where f isthe function giving rise to the distribution.
(If a distribution is not regular, it is called singular.)

Define \left\langle\Lambda_{1}+\Lambda_{2},\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle\Lambda_{1}, \phi\right\rangle+\left\langle\Lambda_{2},\phi\right\rangle, \left\langle c\Lambda,\phi\right\rangle=c\left\langle\Lambda,\phi\right\rangle =\left\langle\Lambda,c\phi\right\rangle, where c is a constant.
More generally, if \alpha(x) is an infinitely differentiable function, then \left\langle\alpha\Lambda,\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle\Lambda,\alpha\phi \right\rangle.

We say that a sequence of distributions \{\Lambda_{n}\} converges to a distribution \Lambda in \mathcal{D}^{*} if \lim_{n\to\infty}\left\langle\Lambda_{n},\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle\Lambda ,\phi\right\rangle for all \phi\in\mathcal{D}(I).
The derivative \Lambda^{\prime} of a distribution is defined by \left\langle\Lambda^{\prime},\phi\right\rangle=-\left\langle\Lambda,\phi^{ \prime}\right\rangle, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}(I).
Similarly \left\langle\Lambda^{(k)},\phi\right\rangle=(-1)^{k}\left\langle\Lambda,\phi^{ (k)}\right\rangle, subject to k=1,2,\dots.
For any locally integrable function f , its distributional derivative is Df=\Lambda^{\prime}_{f}.

\left\langle\delta,\phi\right\rangle=\phi(0), subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}(I), , \left\langle\delta_{x_{0}},\phi\right\rangle=\phi(x_{0}), subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}(I), , \left\langle{\delta_{x_{0}}^{(n)}},\phi\right\rangle=(-1)^{n}\phi^{(n)}(x_{0}), subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}(I).
The Dirac delta distribution is singular.
H\left(x\right)=\begin{cases}1,&x>0,\\ 0,&x\leq 0.\end{cases} , H\left(x-x_{0}\right)=\begin{cases}1,&x>x_{0},\\ 0,&x\leq x_{0}.\end{cases }, D\!H=\delta, , D\!H\left(x-x_{0}\right)=\delta_{x_{0}}.
Suppose f(x) is infinitely differentiable except at x_{0} , where left and right derivatives of all orders exist, and \sigma_{n}=f^{(n)}(x_{0}+)-f^{(n)}(x_{0}-).
Then D^{m}f=f^{(m)}+\sigma_{0}{\delta_{x_{0}}^{(m-1)}}+\sigma_{1}{\delta_{x_{0}}^{( m-2)}}+\dots+\sigma_{m-1}\delta_{x_{0}}, subject to m=1,2,\dots.
For \alpha>-1 , x^{\alpha}_{+}=x^{\alpha}H\left(x\right)=\begin{cases}x^{\alpha},&x>0,\\ 0,&x\leq 0.\end{cases}
For \alpha>0 , Dx^{\alpha}_{+}=\alpha x_{+}^{\alpha-1}.
For \alpha<-1 and \alpha not an integer, define x^{\alpha}_{+}=\frac{1}{(\alpha+1)_{n}}D^{n}x_{+}^{\alpha+n}, where n is an integer such that \alpha+n>-1.
Similarly, we write \ln_{+}x=H\left(x\right)\ln x=\begin{cases}\ln x,&x>0,\\ 0,&x\leq 0,\end{cases} and define (-1)^{n}n!x_{+}^{-1-n}=D^{(n+1)}\ln_{+}x, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots.

The space \mathcal{T}(\mathbb{R}) of test functions for tempered distributions consists of all infinitely-differentiable functions such that the function and all its derivatives are O\left(|x|^{-N}\right) as |x|\to\infty for all N.

A sequence \{\phi_{n}\} of functions in \mathcal{T} is said toconverge to a function \phi\in\mathcal{T} as n\to\infty if the sequence \{\phi_{n}^{(k)}\} converges uniformly to \phi^{(k)} on every finite interval and if the constants c_{k,N} in the inequalities |x^{N}\phi_{n}^{(k)}|\leq c_{k,N} do not depend on n.
A tempered distribution is a continuous linear functional \Lambda on \mathcal{T}.
(See the definition of a distribution in §LABEL:sec:AL.DI.TF.)The set of tempered distributions is denoted by \mathcal{T}^{*}.

A sequence of tempered distributions \Lambda_{n} converges to \Lambda in \mathcal{T}^{*} if \lim_{n\to\infty}\left\langle\Lambda_{n},\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle\Lambda ,\phi\right\rangle, for all \phi\in\mathcal{T}.
The derivatives of tempered distributions are defined in the same way as derivatives of distributions.
For a detailed discussion of tempered distributions see ( ) .
Let \mathcal{D}({\mathbb{R}^{n}})=\mathcal{D}_{n} be the set of all infinitely differentiable functions in n variables, \phi(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}) , with compact support in {\mathbb{R}^{n}}.

If k=(k_{1},\dots,k_{n}) is a multi-index and x=(x_{1},\dots,x_{n})\in{\mathbb{R}^{n}} , then we write x^{k}=x_{1}^{k_{1}}\cdots x_{n}^{k_{n}} and \phi^{(k)}(x)={\partial}^{k}\phi/(\partial x_{1}^{k_{1}}\cdots\partial x_{n}^{ k_{n}}).

A sequence \{\phi_{m}\} of functions in \mathcal{D}_{n} converges to a function \phi\in\mathcal{D}_{n} if the supports of \phi_{m} lie in a fixed compact subset K of {\mathbb{R}^{n}} and \phi_{m}^{(k)} converges uniformly to \phi^{(k)} in K for every multi-index k=(k_{1},k_{2},\dots,k_{n}).
A distribution in {\mathbb{R}^{n}} is a continuous linear functional on \mathcal{D}_{n}.
The partial derivatives of distributions in {\mathbb{R}^{n}} can be defined as in §LABEL:sec:AL.DI.DD.

A locally integrable function f(x)=f(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}) gives rise to a distribution \Lambda_{f} defined by \left\langle\Lambda_{f},\phi\right\rangle=\int_{{\mathbb{R}^{n}}}f(x)\phi(x) \mathrm{d}x, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}_{n}.

The distributional derivative D^{k}f of f is defined by \left\langle D^{k}f,\phi\right\rangle=(-1)^{\left|k\right|}\int_{{\mathbb{R}^{ n}}}f(x)\phi^{(k)}(x)\mathrm{d}x, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{D}_{n}, where k is a multi-index and \left|k\right|=k_{1}+k_{2}+\dots+k_{n}.

For tempered distributions the space of test functions \mathcal{T}_{n} is the set of all infinitely-differentiable functions \phi of n variables that satisfy |x^{m}\phi^{(k)}(x)|\leq c_{m,k}, subject to x\in{\mathbb{R}^{n}}.
Here m=(m_{1},m_{2},\dots,m_{n}) and k=(k_{1},k_{2},\dots,k_{n}) are multi-indices, and c_{m,k} are constants.
Tempered distributions are continuous linear functionals on this space of test functions.
The space of tempered distributions is denoted by \mathcal{T}^{*}_{n}.
Suppose \phi is a test function in \mathcal{T}_{n}.

Then its Fourier transform is \mathscr{F}(\phi)(\mathbf{x})=\mathscr{F}\phi(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2 }}\int_{{\mathbb{R}^{n}}}\phi(\mathbf{t})e^{i\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{t}}\mathrm {d}\mathbf{t}, where \mathbf{x}=(x_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}) and \mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{t}=x_{1}t_{1}+\dots+x_{n}t_{n}.
\mathscr{F}\phi(\mathbf{x}) is also in \mathcal{T}_{n}.
Let \mathbf{D}=\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}},\frac{1}{ \mathrm{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{2}},\ldots,\frac{1}{\mathrm{i}}\frac{ \partial}{\partial x_{n}}\right).

For a multi-index \boldsymbol{{\alpha}}=(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\dots,\alpha_{n}) , define P(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}c_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}\mathbf{x}^ {\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}c_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}x _{1}^{\alpha_{1}}\cdots x_{n}^{\alpha_{n}}, and P(\mathbf{D})=\sum_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}c_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}\mathbf{D}^ {\alpha}=\sum_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}c_{\boldsymbol{{\alpha}}}\left(\frac{1}{ \mathrm{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{1}}\right)^{\alpha_{1}}\dots\left(\frac {1}{\mathrm{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\right)^{\alpha_{n}}.
Here \boldsymbol{{\alpha}} ranges over a finite set of multi-indices, P(\mathbf{x}) is a multivariate polynomial, and P(\mathbf{D}) is a partial differential operator.
Then \mathscr{F}(P(\mathbf{D})\phi)(\mathbf{x})=P(-\mathbf{x})\mathscr{F}\phi( \mathbf{x}), and \mathscr{F}(P\phi)(\mathbf{x})=P(\mathbf{D})\mathscr{F}\phi(\mathbf{x}).

If u\in\mathcal{T}^{*}_{n} is a tempered distribution, then its Fourier transform \mathscr{F}\left(u\right) is defined by \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(u\right),\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle u, \mathscr{F}(\phi)\right\rangle, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}_{n}.

The Fourier transform \mathscr{F}\left(u\right) of a tempered distribution is again a tempered distribution, and \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(P(\mathbf{D})u\right),\phi\right\rangle=\left \langle P_{-}\mathscr{F}\left(u\right),\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathscr{ F}\left(u\right),P_{-}\phi\right\rangle, \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(Pu\right),\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle P( \mathbf{D})\mathscr{F}\left(u\right),\phi\right\rangle, in which P_{-}(\mathbf{x})=P(-\mathbf{x}) ; compare (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.5) and (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.6).

In (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.8) and (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.9) the derivatives in P(\mathbf{D}) are understood to be in the sense of distributions, as defined in §LABEL:sec:AL.DI.DD and we also use the convention (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.TF.6).
We use the notation of the previous subsection and take n=1 and u=\delta in (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.7).

We obtain \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right),\phi\right\rangle=\left\langle \delta,\mathscr{F}(\phi)\right\rangle=\left\langle\delta,\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}\phi(t){\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}xt}}\mathrm{d}t\right \rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\phi(t)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{1 }{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left\langle 1,\phi\right\rangle, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}.

As distributions, the last equation reads \mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}, which is often written conventionally as \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}\delta\left(t\right){\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}xt}}\mathrm{ d}t=1; see also (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.Prop2).

Since \sqrt{2\pi}\mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right)=1 , we have \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(1\right),\phi\right\rangle=\sqrt{2\pi}\left \langle\mathscr{F}\left(\mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right)\right),\phi\right \rangle=\sqrt{2\pi}\left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right),\mathscr{F}(\phi )\right\rangle=\sqrt{2\pi}\left\langle\delta,\mathscr{F}(\mathscr{F}(\phi)) \right\rangle=\sqrt{2\pi}\left\langle\delta,\phi_{-}\right\rangle=\sqrt{2\pi} \phi(0), in which \phi_{-}(x)=\phi(-x).
The second to last equality follows from the Fourier integral formula (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.FInt1).

Since the quantity on the extreme right of (LABEL:eq:AL.FTSD.DD.4) is equal to \sqrt{2\pi}\left\langle\delta,\phi\right\rangle , as distributions, the result in this equation can be stated as \mathscr{F}\left(1\right)=\sqrt{2\pi}\delta, and conventionally it is expressed as \frac{1}{2\pi}\int^{\infty}_{-\infty}{\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}xt}}\mathrm{d}t= \delta\left(x\right); see also (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.FormalInt).

It is easily verified that \operatorname{sign}\left(x\right)=2H\left(x\right)-1, subject to x\neq 0, and from (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.HF.3) we find {\operatorname{sign}^{\prime}}=2H'=2\delta, where H\left(x\right) is the Heaviside function defined in (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.HF.1), and the derivatives are to be understood in the sense of distributions.

Then \mathscr{F}\left({\operatorname{sign}^{\prime}}\right)=\mathscr{F}\left(2H' \right)=2\mathscr{F}\left(\delta\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}, and from (LABEL:eq:AL.DI.FT.8) with u=\operatorname{sign} , P(\mathbf{D})=D , and P_{-}(x)=-ix , we have also \mathscr{F}\left({\operatorname{sign}^{\prime}}\right)=\frac{x}{\mathrm{i}} \mathscr{F}\left(\operatorname{sign}\right).

Coupling (LABEL:eq:AL.FTSD.DD.10) and (LABEL:eq:AL.FTSD.DD.11) gives \mathscr{F}\left(\operatorname{sign}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\,\frac{ \mathrm{i}}{x}, that is \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(\operatorname{sign}\right),\phi\right\rangle= \mathrm{i}\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\pvint^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\phi(x)}{x} \mathrm{d}x.
The Fourier transform of H\left(x\right) now follows from (LABEL:eq:AL.FTSD.DD.5) and (LABEL:eq:AL.FTSD.DD.12).

Indeed, we have \mathscr{F}\left(H\right)=\frac{1}{2}\mathscr{F}\left(1+\operatorname{sign} \right)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\mathscr{F}\left(1\right)+\mathscr{F}\left( \operatorname{sign}\right)\right]=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(\delta+\frac{ \mathrm{i}}{\pi x}\right), that is \left\langle\mathscr{F}\left(H\right),\phi\right\rangle=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}} \phi(0)+\frac{\mathrm{i}}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\pvint^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\phi(x)}{ x}\mathrm{d}x.
For more detailed discussions of the formulas in this section, see ( ) and ( ) .

section.title: Integral and Series Representations of the Dirac Delta

para.sentence: In applications in physics and engineering, the Dirac delta distribution (§LABEL:sec:AL.DI.DDF) is historically and customarily replaced by theDirac delta (or Dirac delta function) \delta\left(x\right).

This is an operator with the properties: \delta\left(x\right)=0, subject to x\in\mathbb{R}, x\neq 0, and \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta\left(x-a\right)\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x=\phi(a), subject to a\in\mathbb{R}, subject to certain conditions on the function \phi(x).

From the mathematical standpoint the left-hand side of (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.Prop2) can be interpreted as a generalized integral in the sense that \lim_{n\to\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta_{n}\left(x-a\right)\phi(x) \mathrm{d}x=\phi(a), for a suitably chosen sequence of functions \delta_{n}\left(x\right) , n=1,2,\dots.
Such a sequence is called a delta sequence and we write, symbolically, \lim_{n\to\infty}\delta_{n}\left(x\right)=\delta\left(x\right), subject to x\in\mathbb{R}.
An example of a delta sequence is provided by \delta_{n}\left(x-a\right)=\sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}}.

In this case \lim_{n\to\infty}\sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}} \phi(x)\mathrm{d}x=\phi(a), for all functions \phi(x) that are continuous when x\in(-\infty,\infty) , and for each a , \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}}\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x converges absolutely for all sufficiently large values of n.
The last condition is satisfied, for example, when \phi(x)=O\left(e^{\alpha x^{2}}\right) as x\to\pm\infty , where \alpha is a real constant.

More generally, assume \phi(x) is piecewise continuous (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.C) when x\in[-c,c] for any finite positive real value of c , and for each a , \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}}\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x converges absolutely for all sufficiently large values of n.
Then \lim_{n\to\infty}\sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}} \phi(x)\mathrm{d}x=\tfrac{1}{2}\phi(a-)+\tfrac{1}{2}\phi(a+).
Formal interchange of the order of integration in the Fourier integral formula ((LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.1) and (LABEL:eq:AL.IT.ft.10)):

\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-iat}\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\phi (x)e^{itx}\mathrm{d}x\right)\mathrm{d}t=\phi(a) yields \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{i(x-a)t} \mathrm{d}t\right)\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x=\phi(a).
The inner integral does not converge.
However, for n=1,2,\dots , \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-t^{2}/(4n)}e^{i(x-a)t}\mathrm{d}t= \sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}}.

Hence comparison with (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.ExDSeq) shows that (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.FInt2) can be interpreted as a generalized integral (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.GenInt) with \delta_{n}\left(x-a\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-t^{2}/(4n) }e^{i(x-a)t}\mathrm{d}t, provided that \phi(x) is continuous when x\in(-\infty,\infty) , and for each a , \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-n(x-a)^{2}}\phi(x)\mathrm{d}x convergesabsolutely for all sufficiently large values of n (as in the case of (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.LimEx)).
Then comparison of (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.Prop2) and (LABEL:eq:AL.RDF.FInt2) yields the formal integral representation \delta\left(x-a\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{i(x-a)t}\mathrm {d}t.
